title: Blog post 1!
text:
Hi! Woah this is so cool! Lets figure out the possibilities of this software! ## TESTING MARKDOWN ### THIS TOO? #### HI! ##### WOAH THATS A LOT OF ‘#’ ###### AARRGGHH. 6 ‘#’! # Now lets explore latex! ## $} a^{b} $ inline \(a^{b}\) not in header hmmm lets try multiline \[
\begin{align}
\text{multiline}\\
\text{multiline}\\
\text{multiline}\\
\text{multiline}\\  
\end{align}
\]
Woah! Nice. Lets reflect on this: We have a super easy way to generate html and css files and make a personal website. This is huge. I’ve always wanted to do this, but never had the excuse or time - and was always way too scared. It was totally unfounded. This is awesome.
In blog style, this shall remain short - but welcome to the start of a fun new adventure in life. Signing off <3 ~ Snow

title: Lab 1 - E155 Startup
text: In this lab, a PCB with FPGA and MCU was assembled andused to drive a 7 segment LED display. Several onboard components were tested, ensuring proper communication between both microcontrollers.

title: Lab 1 - E155 Startup
text: In this lab, a PCB with FPGA and MCU was assembled andused to drive a 7 segment LED display. Several onboard components were tested, ensuring proper communication between both microcontrollers.

title: Lab 1 - E155 Startup
text:
Design and Testing Methodology
The tests for this project exist under two realms - simulation and hardware.

Hardware tests
Three hardware tests were conducted. The first ensured connection between the FPGA and the on-board LEDs, the second required the FPGA to pull a pin on the MCU high, each driving led’s depending on their current state. The third test was using pins on the PCB to control a number displayed on the 7 segment display, as well as on-board LEDS to understand the internal state.


Simulation goals
The 7 segment display code was verified first in simulation due to the extra complexity required. For the simulation, a test bench for each possible user input (switches representing binary numbers 0-9) was constructed.

title: Lab 1 - E155 Startup
Lab 1 - E155 Startup
text:
Results and Discussion
This breif series of tests (15 hours? More?) showed that the hardware is working as expected; The FPGA and MCU were able to properly communicate, and a 7 segment display was properly driven. Further, a 2.4 hz clock signal was generated and used to drive an onboard LED.
All intended tasks were completed successfully. The design could be improved to provide adaptive current. A 7 segment display driven by connections to a constant voltage would allow better control of LED brightness. The present setup distributes current across all leds in the 7 segment display, which decreases the brightness.

Testbench Simulation

title: Lab 1 - E155 Startup
text:
Conclusion
Hours spent in lab: Maybe 15-20? I helped a lot of other people on their project, and also made dumb mistakes (i.e. not realizing it was working properly because the leds were too dim!) that ate a large portion of time. I could probably do this lab again in 1/4 the overall time.
